response.answer_text: That heaven is all about a relationship with God, given freely by Jesus, and not about how hard we work to get God’s approval. Society has often painted God to be the taskmasker or gatekeeper who stands at the gate to mark your exam and either pass or fail you for heaven. But this tragically demeans God as purely examiner and arbiter. This image paints God as someone who we only need to let them into heaven, and don’t need otherwise. The Bible says that God is more than a taskmaster and gatekeeper of heaven, but someone who personally created and loved us. This love doesn’t mean he is not just, he loves us too much to leave us the way we are. His love is demonstrated it on the cross where he basically approves us not because we deserved it, but because of his great love and mercy towards sinners. Very rarely will anyone die for a righteous person, though for a good person someone might possibly dare to die. But God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us. Romans 5:7–8 Approval comes from being accepted as part of his family as his children.  As we know parents love their children and this is independent of what that child does. Sometimes the child will make mistakes but the parent will still care for that child, because of the relationship they have. And when family knock on the door of the house, will they not be let in? The Bible says that those who accept Jesus into their life become a part of the family, and can call God Father and Jesus a friend. This is the reason Christians can say they assuredly have eternal life because of this relationship. They’ve already passed the test. What Jesus has done is imputed onto the person who trusts in him. Jesus invites the repentant sinner to come into God’s house and be part of the family. It means they can enjoy God’s company and goodness in this life and the one to come.   To those seeking God’s approval and hope to reach heaven, let me ask you how much you KNOW God? If not, why should God open his home to you? If you want God’s approval, know that he has already given approval through Jesus. All you need to do is become Jesus’s friend by accepting his death and resurrection and asking him to come into your life, and you will receive not only eternal life, but an eternal and perfect relationship of love. And because you are his friend, you will not only be welcomed but treated as one of family.

The temples? It turns out that both temples were destroyed on the same day. I knew that God had a hand in this and that He was giving us a clue that we are to understand. But what does it mean? The Messiah King Cyrus (written about in scripture before he was born) freed the Jews to build a new temple. The Messiah Jesus Christ warned that the temple would be destroyed. After standing for 586 years the temple was destroyed by the Romans in 70 AD on the 9th of Av. But that is not the kicker. I kept searching and using the very ancient belief of God`s seven thousand year plan I estimated the year between these events and came up with 261 BC. These events had to be repeating and going into reverse order for a reason. I immediately put it into Google and saw the Hebrew Calendar. I went to the site and put in 261 BC and when I saw the results, no joke, I literally almost fell off of my chair: 261 BC = 3500–3501 HEBREW CALENDAR But the single greatest surprise I found in the Bible is that GOD is coming to the Earth to live here. 3 And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying, “Behold, the dwelling place of God is with man. He will dwell with them, and they will be his people, and God himself will be with them as their God. - REVELATION 21 For some this may feel like Calculus 3 on the first day of Kindergarten. If so, step back for some days and then come back to think about it.

“What is the greatest thing we learn from the Bible?” Don’t believe everything you read! And I am not being facetious here - more trouble has been caused by people misunderstanding the biblical text, than for almost any other reason, apart from greed, selfishness and xenophobia. People routinely accept and put into action doctrines that were never meant for them: God’s command, ‘Go forth and multiply’ was intended for Adam and Eve and their offspring, but God-fearing humans are still reproducing like rabbits and destroying the planetApplying certain verses, products of their milieu to justify racism (Ham was cursed, therefore all people of colour should serve the Semites & Whites!).Xenophobia & racial “cleansing” (Joshua murdered whole communities at God’s command).Repentance (hence the Roman Catholic’s misuse of penance, Magdalene Laundries etc.Discrimination (hence the persecution of Jews, Wiches, Communists, Gays - & non-heterosexual behaviour, and of anyone who is different) .& since Jesus & Paul both accepted slavery, it must be OK, mustn’t it?Read the Bible (or any work of non-fiction, for that matter) in context and be aware of when something was written & whether it really is an eternal truth (“You shall not murder”), or a cultural one (“Women must cover their heads in church”) - the former must be obeyed and used as foundations for our lives, the latter can be safely ignored. One just has to learn the difference. A friend of mine, who suffered badly from schizophrenia, tended to apply everything in the Bible literally - I was quietly amused one day when I found him outside a fish & chip shop praying, asking God whether he should have a chicken & mushroom pie, or a steak and kidney one! He was, of course, “taking everything to the Lord in prayer”!

To answer this, we must go beyond our 21st century thinking and see it from the writer’s point of view. If you do that, you will find some common themes that go right through. The most well known of these is blood but I’ll talk about two others because I’m not convinced about that one really. The first is faith. I mean real faith. Not just the 21st century version but one that changes your life because you depend on the one you have faith in. So you act before you know. This was the greatest sin of ‘Adam’ - his faith was seriously lacking. He wanted to know before he acted. Therefore he saw the fruit and saw that it looked nice and juicy so he ate. His faith in God didn’t go as far as obeying what God had told him. Noah’s faith trusted that God would keep his word and it made him build a boat. Moses risked his life facing Pharaoh, telling him off, giving him some demands, He then risked a lot of peoples’ lives by leading them into the desert. Very often, he acted before he knew and it changed his own life - and pharaoh’s - and the Egyptians - and the Hebrews. David faced Goliath - long before he knew what would happen. Nathan risked his life by giving David a telling off Elijah faced the prophets of Baal and upset the king and queen. Jeremiah kept telling various kings what was about to happen Daniel risked being thrown to the lions. But I reckon by a miles and miles, the greatest example was Jesus and especially his prayer “Not my will, but yours.” For that put into motion 24 hours of increasing suffering. Arrest, 5 trials (Caiaphas, Annas, Pilate, Herod, Pilate again), all with severe beating. Then an official beating, a crown of thorns (you can try this one at home) and finally a humiliating (naked) excruciating death. Second is love. We don’t touch it today - not like they did. The Hebrew word (or it’s adjective - I’m no linguist) is rather untranslatable but it turns up all through the Hebrew Old Testament and also the Greek New Testament via the Septuagint translation of the Old. In the Old, various versions and various circumstances translate as limitless, loving-kindness, steadfast, faithful, pity, mercy, compassionate, fidelity, covenant, troth, loyalty, pledge, eager, keen, strength and probably others. Into the New Testament it comes out as grace (as do other Hebrew words I think - though I’m not a theologian). I think the broadness of meaning in that word is well known. Think about ‘covenant love’. It’s a two way thing. Only one side needs to break the covenant and it all goes up in smoke. It’s a promise of fideity and you can’t go go back on it. In those days, you were as good as your word. Whatever you promise, no matter how much it hurts, you keep it. Thus, God did keep his side of the bargain and we then get ‘steadfast love’. Bacause he was faithful and we were not, we then get ‘compassionate love’ We talk about love. Ha ha ha - we haven’t a clue.

Thanks for the A2A! This answer is actually really hard. There are many great things that we learn from the Bible, and many are very connected. If I may, I would say that there are three equally great things learned from the Bible. First, man is sinful. Second, God requires death as payment for sin. Third, sacrifice can save us. There will be a TL;DR at the end. Man is Sinful The first is that man is sinful. From the Garden of Eden onward, man just waits for the opportunity to disobey God, to not trust Him, and to follow their own wills. In Genesis 6:5, “The Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually;” in Genesis 8:21, the Lord promises “‘I will never again curse the ground because of man, for the intention of man's heart is evil from his youth.’” These verses lay it out plainly: men and their hearts are corrupt and evil from their youth. David further noted that this inclination goes all the way back to the womb! Psalm 51:5 records David as saying “I was born in sin, and in iniquity my mother conceived me.” This does not mean that the act of procreation is sinful; if it were, God would not have commanded Adam and Eve to “be fruitful and multiply” before their sin in the Garden. What else can it mean, then? That man is conceived “in iniquity” and “born in sin” can only mean that man is born with an inherent, sinful nature. Jeremiah spells it out plainly in 17:9 “The heart is deceitful above all else and desperately sick. Who can know it?” Isaiah is very descriptive in 64:6 “[A]ll our righteous deeds are like a polluted garment.” The Hebrew for “polluted garment” is ed behged; the phrase is used to refer to used menstrual cloths. Isaiah tells us that our best deeds are like used tampons to God. You may ask: “How is this great?” The reason this is great is twofold. First, it is great because a difficult truth is always more liberating than a nice lie. Second, it is great because all humans actually want justice, and just punishment is deserved for those who have wronged us. Unfortunately, that means that we will deserve our just punishment. All of this leads us into our next point. God Requires Death as Payment for Sin God is just, and punishes sin justly. From the beginning, He has told us that the just punishment for sin is death. The reason is that sin separates us from God. God is Holy. We tend to think of holy as “righteous” or “good;” these are certainly part of His character, but they have nothing to do with the word “holy” in the Bible. “Holy” in the Bible is the word “qadosh” and comes from “qodesh;” both mean “being apart.” Holy, then, means that God is separate, set apart, from us. From the beginning, God bridged that gap between us; we did not. In the Garden, God came and walked with Adam; Adam did not ascend to heaven to be with God. Therefore, separation from God is because of who He is. It is not the only reason, however, that God is set apart from us. Our natural separation from God was twisted and perverted by mankind’s sin. “Sin” in Hebrew is “chata” meaning “to miss” or “to go awry.” Man missed God’s standard in Genesis by choosing to disobey Him. From that day, we have been separated by God not only by our nature but by our choices. God is also just. By His nature, He is concerned with justice and righteousness. Here, His righteousness comes into play. As long as Adam kept His command, God could come down to man and be with us. His command, though, came with a penalty for breaking it. That penalty was death. You may ask “Why death? Why not a more mild punishment, one that fit the crime better?” Because when man is separated from God by sin, God will not bridge that gap unless justice is done; if He did, it would not be just, and therefore He would not be God, and all reality (sustained by Him) would shatter. Separation from God that He will not bridge brings death, decay, and ruin, because it is only by His power that life is sustained. If you cut yourself off from the source of life, then death is the natural consequence. The problem was not eating the fruit. The problem was that eating the fruit constituted voluntary and permanent separation from God; the act of violating God’s command is, in essence, telling God to shove off and leave us alone. God, by His just nature, is willing and able to honor that request. This brings nothing but death. Again, you may ask, why is this great? Well, again, the truth, no matter how distasteful, is more liberating than a lie, no matter how comforting. Now, the third point. God has Allowed Sacrifice to Save Us From the Garden onward, the penalty for sin in the eyes of God was always death of the one who sinned. However, God would, in the case of a repentant person, accept the death of another in their own place. This is known as “substitutionary sacrifice.” From the first sin, substitution was implemented. Let us observe the Garden of Eden account. God told Adam (who instructed Eve) that they were allowed to eat any fruit and plant that they wanted in the Garden, with one exception. They were not allowed to eat from the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. God told them that if they ate of it, on that very day, they would surely die. There were no ifs, ands, or buts about it. They would die. Therefore, when they ate, and God confronted them, their deserved penalty was death. However, they were given a stay of execution, as it were. God instead banished them from the garden. By separating them from the Garden, and the Tree of Life in it, God condemned them to die. Notice, however, what Genesis 3:21 says He did first: “And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skins and clothed them.” God clothed them in garments made of skin; this was animal skin, to be precise. Why? Why not let them clothe themselves in hide and leather clothes? Why should God involve Himself in this kind of violent act, clothing them in the skins of the very animals that Adam named and was supposed to care for? Because, the earned payment for sin is, in fact, death. For us to live and draw close to God, something has to die in our place. In other words, there must be a substitutionary sacrifice in order for men to be near to God. Notice the incredibly clear picture at Passover: the angel of death is kept out by a house with the blood of a lamb! “Something has already died here! There is no need for death in this house!” The soul who sins shall die, but God allows the death of another in their place to fulfill His divine justice. This is great because it gives us hope. We accept the truths of our own sinfulness and God’s holiness; we see exactly how far we are from God. There is nothing that we can do to bridge that gap. However, God has made a way for us to be made close to Him. Christians hold that the sacrifice of animals was intended to foreshadow the Perfect Sacrifice. Enter, Jesus. He was a man; therefore, He knew our sins, our weaknesses, and our temptations first-hand, and He could be the new representative for our race. Adam was the first, and plunged us into sin; Christ was the second, and can now raise us up to God. Moreover, as a man, He could taste death. However, He was also God. This meant that He could do what no other could do: live a perfect and sinless life. His blood could also be effective throughout all of time, both retroactively into the past and forward into the future, for those who trust and have faith in God. Finally, being God meant that He could, in fact, bear the punishment for all sins at all times. No mere human could bear it. As Paul wrote in 2 Corinthians: “He became sin, who knew no sin, in order that we might become the righteousness of God.” In this way, He fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah 53: “But he was pierced for our transgressions; he was crushed for our iniquities; upon him was the chastisement that brought us peace, and with his wounds we are healed.” TL;DR These three work together to show us that we have no hope in ourselves. God, however, has given us hope. This truth is more liberating than any lie, no matter how comforting. That makes it great.

Hmm. What an interesting question. Everything I can think of comes back to one thing: Love. God’s love for us and how He wants us to love each other (And Himself). The trouble is, most of us don’t understand what love is. It’s such a complex thing that the Greek’s had FOUR words for it: Agapeo: Unconditional love; the love of God for mankind. This is an ACTION kind of love, as in “For God so loved the world….” John 3:16 It is also a sacrificial type of love, doing whatever is necessary for the best interest of the loved one. Phileo: Love between friends. This answer taken from Greek Agape, Phileo, Eros, Storge It would probably be helpful if phileo were never translated "love" in the New Testament, because it refers to a strong liking or a strong friendship. Of course, we see how phileo gets translated "love," because in modern culture we say we "love" things that we strongly like: "I love ice cream," "I love my car," "I love the way your hair looks," etc. The word phileo implies a strong emotional connection, and thus is used of the "love," or deep friendship, between friends. You can agape your enemies, but you cannot phileo them. The difference between agape and phileo becomes very clear in John 21:15, but unfortunately it is obscured in almost all English translations. After being raised from the dead, Jesus met Peter. Here is the short version of what they said to each other: Jesus: Simon…do you love (agape) me more than these [fish?]. Peter: Yes, Lord; you know that I love (phileo) you.  Jesus: Simon…do you…love (agape) me?  Peter: Yes, Lord, you know that I love (phileo) you.  Jesus: Simon…do you love (phileo) me?  Peter: [Grieved] "Lord…you know that I love (phileo) you." In this example, you can clearly see how using the simple word "love" has obscured the true deeper meaning of their conversation. Eros: The sense of being in love; romantic love The meaning is obvious. Is often mistaken for lust. <wry grin> Been there, done that, especially when a teenager. Storge: Love of family; Parent/child, siblings, cousins, etc. In a very close family, agape is felt as well. Storge can also exist between husbands and wives in strong marriages, helping them survive the slings and arrows of life. So, between the four Greek words for love, we can see all that love can be, and all that we are intended to know of love. And God IS Love. :-)

The Bible is a collection of Christian texts that is the result of refinement by men who thought they were led by God to discern his teachings. The early Christian world was diverse and everyone had a different take on the Gospel of Jesus. These disagreements were “settled” in large meetings of high ranking priests called “Councils.” The Council of Hippo (one of the African Synods) drew up a collection of texts, which is now the Catholic Bible (including a class of texts I as a Protestant would call Apocrypha), in 393 AD. St. Jerome is credited with creating the Old Latin Vulgate, which was the outcome of the African Synods and was used as the Bible for centuries. The Bible is an unreliable authority because it contains numerous contradictions. Logically, if two statements are contradictory, at least one of them is false. The biblical contradictions therefore prove that the book has many false statements and is not infallible. Examples of Old Testament Contradictions The contradictions start in the opening chapters of the Bible, where inconsistent creation stories are told. Genesis chapter 1 says the first man and woman were made at the same time, and after the animals. But Genesis chapter 2 gives a different order of creation: man, then the animals, and then woman. Genesis chapter 1 lists six days of creation, whereas chapter 2 refers to the “day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens.” Genesis 1:2-3 claims that God created light and divided it from darkness on the first day; but Genesis 1:14-19 tells us the sun, moon, and stars weren’t made until the fourth day. Chapter 1 reports that the fruit trees were created before the man, while chapter 2 indicates they were made after him. Genesis 1:20 says the fowl were created out of the waters; Genesis 2:19 alleges they were formed from the ground. Contradictions are also seen in the biblical story of a worldwide flood. According to Genesis 6:19-22, God ordered Noah to bring “of every living thing of all flesh, two of every sort . . . into the ark.” Nevertheless, Genesis 7:2-3 relates that the Lord ordered Noah to take into the ark the clean beasts and the birds by sevens, and only the unclean beasts by twos. Genesis 8:4 reports that, as the waters of the flood receded, Noah’s ark rested on the mountains of Ararat in the seventh month. The very next verse, however, says the mountaintops could not be seen until the tenth month. Genesis 8:13 describes the earth as being dry on the first day of the first month. But Genesis 8:14 informs us the earth was not dry until the twenty-seventh day of the second month. The Old Testament contains an interesting contradiction in the story of the census taken by King David and the resulting punishment of the Israelites. God was so angered by the census that he sent a plague that killed 70,000 men. According to II Samuel 24:1, the Lord had caused David to take the census – which makes the punishment appear even more nonsensical. But an attempt was later made, at I Chronicles 21:1, to improve God’s image by claiming that Satan incited the census. Further, the Old Testament is contradictory as to whether the Lord commanded the Israelites to sacrifice animals to him. At Jeremiah 7:22, God denies he ever gave the Israelites commandments about animal sacrifices. In contrast, Exodus 29:38-42 and many other verses depict God as requiring the Israelites to offer animal sacrifices. Examples of New Testament Contradictions In the New Testament, there are contradictions between the genealogies of Jesus given in the first chapter of Matthew and the third chapter of Luke. Both genealogies begin with Jesus’ father, who is identified as Joseph (which is curious, given that Mary was supposedly impregnated by the Holy Ghost). But Matthew says Joseph’s father was Jacob, while Luke claims he was Heli. Matthew lists 26 generations between Jesus and King David, whereas Luke records 41. Matthew runs Jesus’ line of descent through David’s son Solomon, while Luke has it going through David’s son Nathan. The story of Jesus’ birth is also contradictory. Matthew 2:13-15 depicts Joseph and Mary as fleeing to Egypt with the baby Jesus immediately after the wise men from the east had brought gifts. But Luke 2:22-40 claims that after the birth of Jesus, his parents remained in Bethlehem for the time of Mary’s purification (which was 40 days, under the Mosaic law). Afterwards, they brought Jesus to Jerusalem “to present him to the Lord,” and then returned to their home in Nazareth. Luke mentions no journey into Egypt or visit by wise men from the east. Concerning the death of Judas, the disloyal disciple, Matthew 27:5 states he took the money he had received for betraying Jesus, threw it down in the temple, and “went and hanged himself.” To the contrary, Acts 1:18 claims Judas used the money to purchase a field and “falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out.” In describing Jesus being led to his execution, John 19:17 recounts that he carried his own cross. But Mark 15:21-23 disagrees by saying a man called Simon carried the cross. As for the crucifixion, Matthew 27:44 tells us Jesus was taunted by both criminals who were being crucified with him. But Luke 23:39-43 relates that only one of the criminals taunted Jesus, the other criminal rebuked the one who was doing the taunting, and Jesus told the criminal who was defending him, “Today shalt thou be with me in paradise.” Regarding the last words of Jesus while on the cross, Matthew 27:46 and Mark 15:34 quote Jesus as crying with a loud voice, “My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?” Luke 23:46 gives his final words as, “Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit.” John 19:30 alleges the last words were, “It is finished.” There are even contradictions in the accounts of the resurrection – the supposed event that is the very foundation of the Christian religion. Mark 16:2 states that on the day of the resurrection, certain women arrived at the tomb at the rising of the sun. But John 20:1 informs us they arrived when it was yet dark. Luke 24:2 describes the tomb as open when the women arrived, whereas Matthew 28:1-2 indicates it was closed. Mark 16:5 declares that the women saw a young man at the tomb, Luke 24:4 says they saw two men, Matthew 28:2 reports they saw an angel, and John 20:11-12 claims they saw two angels. Also in the resurrection stories, there are contradictions as to the identity of the women who came to the tomb,[7] whether the men or angels the women saw were inside or outside the tomb,[8] whether the men or angels were standing or sitting,[9] and whether Mary Magdalene recognized the risen Jesus when he first appeared to her.[10] As a final example of a New Testament contradiction, the conflicting accounts of Paul’s conversion can be cited. Acts 9:7 states that when Jesus called Paul to preach the gospel, the men who were with Paul heard a voice but saw no man. According to Acts 22:9, however, the men saw a light but didn’t hear the voice speaking to Paul. The foregoing examples are just a few of the hundreds of contradictions contained in the Old and New Testaments. Each contradiction is an instance where at least one of the verses is wrong. Thus, hundreds of contradictions mean there are at least hundreds of incorrect statements in the Bible.

The Bible is in two parts, the Hebrew Bible or Old Testament, and the Christian Bible or New Testament. Each should be understood as an ecletic set of documents which happened to have survived and have been put together by committees. The Hebrew Bible gives us a rare insight into Bronze age people beyond many of the official records. We actually know the names and family relationships of many early people, along with their myths and many of their cultural practices. A lot of what we learn is not pleasant by today’s moral standards, but probably was typical of other peoples of the time. They boast of their achievements and whine of their defeats, attributing victories to moral superiority (as is usual throughout history) and explaining losses as the action of supernatural forces. It actually represents a remarkable survival of oral history and some later written documents. The discipline of the Jewish scribes in copying is breathtaking. They had systems for counting letters in order to check, and thus made relatively few changes considering the number of times that documents have been copied. Their care in transcribing things which they did not understand is only occasionally broken by someone deciding “that can’t be right” and “correcting it”. For example, Methuselah was given a lifetime of a thousand years (i.e. a very approximate value, and most probably meaning a very long time) later corrected to 969 years by someone doing sums and deciding that he could not have survived the flood. (The great ages and some apparent contradictions come from a misunderstanding of the two early counting systems.) Modern translations may also include “corrections” by people who honestly think they know better than earlier translators and are trying to make the story more acceptable to current audiences. In reading it is important to recognise the inherent bias. For example we have no documents from the Philistines, who would probably have spoken badly of the Jews. Nevertheless it is difficult for a modern person to sympathize with Hebrew justification of genocide and praise for murder of innocents on a grand scale, whether Egyptians or Canaanites. It may be helpful to understand that there were once two kingdoms, Israel and Judah, which probably had slightly different collections of historical and religious scrolls, which have been combined. Thus many accounts (starting with Adam and Eve) appear twice with contradictions. Where the scholars who combined them could not decide which was more reliable, they have included both. This is the source of many “Bible contradictions” which are not a problem if you treat them like the variations we find in accounts of events in other histories. It should be obvious that these people had little idea of the size of the world and only connection with a limited area, so could not possibly know if (for example) a flood was worldwide. Indicating both bias and limited view, we can look at the account of the crossing of the Reed Sea (not Red Sea). It is plausible that the Egyptians sent a small detachment of cavalry after runaway slaves who had helped themselves to items of value on the way out, and got stuck in some mud. It is less likely that they were given treasure as they claim and that “all the armies of the Egyptians” perished in crossing the Reed Sea, as this would be likely to appear in the historical record. By the way, it is likely that the word currently translated as “thousand” in accounts of the Exodus meant “tent group” or the leader of a family which would camp together, as observed by the great Egyptologist Flinders Petrie long ago, and rediscovered by several scholars since. It is generally accepted that “forty” was commonly a figure of speech for “many” and therefore should not be used for precise calculations of the historical record. The Christian New Testament again gives an insight into the work of committees with a bias and limited view selecting documents to promote their agenda. It is if anything less reliable than the Hebrew Bible, as much of it was written and edited very much later than the events described and in the context of particular interpretations. The Gospel of Matthew has in fact been made up of cutting and pasting together many variants, and early versions do not have a virgin birth. The purported early life of Jesus is best understood in terms of its mythic context and fitting in with other traditions. Michael Ramsey (Archbishop of Canterbury) said that these stories were not essential to the messages of Christianity, but had probably helped in marketing (my word, not his). I pesonally think the most important lesson from this part of the Bible is that what is called Christianity is in fact Paulism. That is, most of the rules commonly given as “Christian teaching” come from the letters of St Paul (plus convenient selections from the Hebrew Bible, generally omitting the nasty bits). There are relatively few direct instructions from Jesus, even if you trust the text.
